metadata.title: Effects of pretreatment atmosphere and silver loading on the structure and catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts

IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8640 S1381-1169(13)00030-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.01.017 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (A) and pore size distribution (B) of 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after (a) O2, (b) Ar and (c) H2 pretreatment. Fig. 2 TEM images of 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after (a) O2, (b) Ar and (c) H2 pretreatment. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of (a) O2–8% Ag/SBA-15, (b) Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15 and (c) H2–8% Ag/SBA-15. Fig. 4 Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra of (A) 2wt%, (B) 8wt%, (C) 4wt% and (D) 6wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after (a) O2, (b) Ar and (c) H2 pretreatment. Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of (A) 2wt% and (B) 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after (a) O2, (b) Ar and (c) H2 pretreatment. Fig. 6 Schematic model of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts with various Ag loading pretreated under different atmosphere. Fig. 7 CO oxidation activity of (A) 2wt% and (B) 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after (a) O2, (b) Ar and (c) H2 pretreatment. Fig. 8 TOF of Ag/SBA-15 with different silver loading for CO oxidation after pretreatment with O2 and Ar. Fig. 9 The O2-TPD spectra of 2wt% and 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after pretreatment with O2 and Ar. Table 1 Physicochemical parameters of 2wt% and 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 pretreated with different atmospheres at 500°C. Samples BET a (m2/g) V b (cc/g) P c (nm) O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 608 1.01 6.63 Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 615 0.99 6.68 H2–2% Ag/SBA-15 612 1.01 6.62 O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 592 1.01 6.62 Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15 590 0.94 6.65 H2–8% Ag/SBA-15 591 1.01 6.61 a BET specific surface. b Total pore volume. c The pore diameter calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the BJH method. Effects of pretreatment atmosphere and silver loading on the structure and catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts Xiaodong Zhang Zhenping Qu ⁎ Fangli Yu Yi Wang Xin Zhang Key Laboratory of Industrial Ecology and Environmental Engineering (MOE), School of Environmental Science and Technology, Dalian University of Technology, Linggong Road 2, Dalian 116024, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 155 4266 3636; fax: +86 411 8470 8083. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Catalyst structure was related with the pretreatment conditions and silver loading. ► Ar pretreatment gave higher activity on the catalyst with low silver loading. ► Small metal Ag was key factor for high activity on the catalyst with low loading. ► High activity was obtained on catalyst with high loading after O2 pretreatment. ► Subsurface oxygen species was essential for high activity after O2 pretreatment. The structural properties of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts with various Ag loading after pretreatment under different atmosphere, i.e., O2, Ar and H2, in relation to their activities on CO oxidation were investigated. N2 adsorption–desorption results showed that the pretreatment atmosphere had a negligible effect on the physical structure of all catalysts. Interestingly, it was found that different pretreatment atmosphere (Ar, O2) and Ag loading exhibited a large difference on the structure of silver catalyst and their catalytic activity. For Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low silver loading (≤6wt%), Ar pretreatment resulted in the highest activity for CO oxidation. However, the highest catalytic performance was observed after oxygen pretreatment over the silver catalyst with high loading (>6wt%). UV–vis and H2-TPR results showed Ar pretreatment and Ag loading strongly affected the states of Ag species for the silver catalysts, which were changed from metal Ag (≤4wt%) to a mixture of Ag and Ag2O (≥6wt%). Moreover Ar pretreatment was favorable for the formation of small Ag particles for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low Ag loading. When the silver loading is increased, the heavy aggregation of silver particles occurred after Ar pretreatment, resulting in the decrease of TOF for CO oxidation. O2 pretreatment was conductive to the formation of subsurface oxygen species on the larger silver particles for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with high Ag loading, which resulted in the increase of TOF for CO oxidation. It was evident that small metal Ag particles was key factor of the higher catalytic activity for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low Ag loading, while a large number of subsurface oxygen species played an important effect on the higher catalytic activity for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with high Ag loading. Keywords Ag/SBA-15 CO oxidation Pretreatment atmosphere Ag loading 1 Introduction Recently, supported Ag catalysts have attracted tremendous attention owing to their unique catalytic activity properties for various reactions, in particular, for CO oxidation at low temperatures [1–10]. It is found that the Ag species state and Ag particle size along with the metal-support interface have been suggested to play a decisive role in controlling the activity of the Ag catalysts [4–7]. These three factors are largely determined by the preparation method and the activation or pretreatment conditions before reaction [4–7]. Among the various routes used to prepare supported Ag catalysts, the conventional impregnation technique is the most common method [5]. The main feature in the impregnation method is that the Ag catalyst needs additional pretreatment to decompose AgNO3. Jin et al. reported that Ag/SiO2 prepared by room temperature γ-ray irradiation showed an inferior low temperature catalytic activity and a better stability compared with Ag/SiO2 prepared by calcination. The different catalytic behavior is associated with the various crystalline sizes of silver nanoparticles in Ag/SiO2 prepared under different atmospheres [1]. Gac et al. reported that the catalytic activity of Ag catalysts is related to the pretreatment atmosphere and the dispersion of crystallites or the formation of strong silver–oxygen bounding; moreover, the reduction of catalysts is necessary to obtain high activity [8]. Our previous studies indicated that high temperature oxygen treatment prior to hydrogen reduction is necessary for Ag/SiO2 catalyst to show high activities [7]. Clearly, the atmosphere in treatment and activation process is a key factor and can exert a significant influence on the final structure and activity of supported Ag catalysts. Mesoporous silica materials are an ideal host for metallic nanoparticles due to high surface area, uniform pore size distribution and well-defined pores [11,12]. Recently, we have successfully prepared highly ordered Ag/SBA-15 catalysts by in situ “pH-adjusting” method, which showed a high catalytic activity for CO oxidation [6]. It has been also found that the pH value of synthesis solution strongly affects the formation of Ag2O inside the channels, and more Ag2O formed inside the channels leads to the decrease of catalytic activity. And it is also found that the oxygen adsorbate induced decrease in the surface free energy at 900°C induces the evaporated silver atoms to be re-deposited on the support and meanwhile diffuse into the channels of SBA-15, forming more highly dispersed small silver particles inside the channels [13]. However, detailed studies on structure of Ag/SBA-15 catalyst prepared by impregnation method under different pretreatment atmospheres have not been undertaken. Moreover, the relationship of the effect of pretreatment atmospheres and Ag loading on the structure of silver catalysts has never been investigated in detail. Thus in this paper, the influence of pretreatment atmosphere and Ag loading on the structure and catalytic activity for CO oxidation of Ag/SBA-15 catalyst was investigated systematically and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation SBA-15 was synthesized by using triblock copolymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20) as a structure directing agent according to the procedure reported by Zhao et al. [12]. In a typical preparation, 4g of triblock copolymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20) was dissolved in 125mL of HCl solution (2M). Under stirring, 8.5g TEOS was added and the mixture was stirred continuously for 4h at 40°C. The final molar ratio was TEOS:P123:HCl:H2O=1:0.017:5.8:155. The mixture was aged at 100°C for 48h in a polypropylene bottle. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solid was recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water and dried under ambient conditions. Then, the product was subjected to thermal treatment to remove P123. The resulting powders were calcined at about 540°C for 10h in air to obtain SBA-15 support. Ag/SBA-15 catalysts were prepared by the same method as that previously reported [7]. The support was immersed with a certain amount of AgNO3 precursor solution (weight loading of 2, 4, 6, and 8%) under stirring. The as-prepared AgNO3/SBA-15 sample was aged at room temperature overnight and then dried at 70°C for 12h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Routine X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out on a Rigaku D/max-γb X-ray diffractometer with monochromatic detector. Copper Kα radiation was used, with a power setting of 40kV and 100mA, and a scan rate of 5°/min. TEM experiments were performed with the JEM-2000EX microscope, using an accelerating voltage of 100kV. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at about −196°C were measured using a Quantachrome SI gas sorption analyzer. The specific surface area was calculated by using the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) model. TPR experiments were performed with a ChemBET PULSAR TPR/TPD under 10vol.% H2 flow diluted with Ar gas. 0.1g catalyst was exposed to a flow of H2/Ar mixture. The temperature was ramped from room temperature to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Light absorption properties were measured using UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (JASCO, 60 UV-550) with a wavelength range of 200–800nm. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiment was carried out in a setup coupled with a quadrupole mass spectrometer. Before experiment, the catalyst was pretreated under different atmospheres and then cooled under He to room temperature. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements CO oxidation activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor (6mm outside diameter) at atmospheric pressure and with 0.2g of catalyst. The reactants were fed with a volume ratio of He/CO/O2 =79/1/20 at a total flow rate of 30mLmin−1, which was controlled by an independent thermal mass flow controller. Prior to the reaction, the catalysts were pretreated with 30mLmin−1 of O2, Ar and H2 at 500°C for 2h, respectively. For the sake of clarity, the as-treated catalysts were referred to O2–x% Ag/SBA-15, Ar–x% Ag/SBA-15 and H2–x% Ag/SBA-15, where the x is the weight loading of Ag. On-line gas chromatograph (GC 7890II) with a TCD detector was employed to measure the reactor inlet and outlet effluent gas streams. 5A molecular sieves column (3m×3mm) was used to separate oxygen, carbon monoxide. In this paper, the CO conversion was calculated from the change of the CO concentration: CO conversion = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 % where [CO]in is the inlet CO concentration and [CO]out is the outlet CO concentration. The activity of a given catalyst is expressed in terms of the temperature corresponding to the catalytic efficiency higher than 98% (T 98), which was obtained from the curve of catalytic efficiency versus reaction temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore diameter distributions of 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts pretreated with O2, Ar and H2, respectively. All catalysts still remain typical IV adsorption–desorption isotherms with H1-type hysteresis, indicating that the ordered mesoporous structures of SBA-15 are not deteriorated [12]. The physical properties of all catalysts have been summarized in Table 1 . The surface area, the pore size and the total pore volume of various 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts are almost in the same range. That is to say that pretreatment atmosphere has a negligible effect on the physical structure of Ag catalysts. And the similar result is also obtained on 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts (shown in Table 1). Various Ag/SBA-15 catalysts were characterized by XRD technique. No obvious diffraction peaks of silver or silver compounds are detected on various 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts. TEM was then used as a complementary technique to examine the structures of the catalysts and the Ag particles size. Representative TEM images for various catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be observed that all catalysts show well-ordered hexagonal arrays of pores, uniform, regular and ordered pore channels. The mean size of Ag nanoparticles follows the order H2–2% Ag/SBA-15 (18nm)>O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 (10nm)>Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 (7nm). Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts after different pretreatments. All samples exhibit four intense diffraction peaks at 38.2°, 44.2°, 64.4°, 77.1°, which correspond to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) lattice planes of the cubic structure of Ag, respectively. A broad peak at about 2θ =22° is observed, corresponding to the amorphous part of the support silica. The Ag crystallite size, calculated by the Scherrer's equation, follows the trend: H2–8% Ag/SBA-15 (21.8nm)>Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15 (18.5nm)>O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 (11.9nm). In addition, the size of Ag particle over 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 is larger than that over 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 under same treatment atmosphere. UV–vis characterization was performed to investigate the details of the state of the supported Ag catalysts. Fig. 4(A) shows the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of various 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts. UV–vis analysis demonstrates the existence of different states of the Ag species. O2–2% Ag/SBA-15, Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 and H2–2% Ag/SBA-15 show the characteristic surface plasma resonance (SPR) peak of Ag nanoparticles at 405, 429 and 417nm, respectively [14]. In addition, O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 also shows a peak at 220nm whereas Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 and H2–2% Ag/SBA-15 do not. The band centered at 220nm is attributed to the 4d10 to 4d95s1 transition of highly dispersed Ag+ ions [15,16]. Usually, a redshift of the SPR peak with the decrease of particle size can be observed, which is induced by the strong matrix effect for supported metal nanoparticles [1,14]. Pan et al. also reported that calcination of Ag particles in mesoporous SiO2 leads to the aggregation of Ag particles accompanied by the great blueshift of the SPR peak [16]. TEM results clearly show that the size of Ag nanoparticles follows the order H2–2% Ag/SBA-15>O2–2% Ag/SBA-15>Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15. However, the SPR peak position in O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 happen blueshift compared with that in H2–2% Ag/SBA-15 although the particles in O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 are smaller than those in H2–2% Ag/SBA-15. Jin et al. reported Ag2O species also affected the SPR signal except matrix effect, and resulting in a blueshift of the SPR peak even if the particle size is smaller [1]. There exists more complex environment, such as Ag species effect, in O2–2% Ag/SBA-15 than in H2–2% Ag/SBA-15. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of various 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4(B). For O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 and Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15, two bands assigned to the Ag+ and Ag nanoparticles are discriminated. While for H2–8% Ag/SBA-15, only one band centered at 396nm is observed. A blueshift of the SPR peak with the increasing particle size is observed. The size of Ag nanoparticles follows the order H2–8% Ag/SBA-15>Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15>O2–8% Ag/SBA-15. This is also consistent with the previous XRD results (Fig. 3). Combining with above TEM and XRD results, under the same Ag loading, Ar pretreatment is favorable for the formation of small Ag particles for 2wt% Ag/SBA-15, while relatively smaller Ag particles are obtained after oxygen pretreatment for 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts compared with Ar treatment. In order to well understand the relationship of the effects of O2 and Ar atmosphere on the structure (particle size and species state) of silver catalyst with different Ag loading, the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of 4 and 6wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4(C) and (D), respectively. O2–4 (6)% Ag/SBA-15 shows a peak at 220nm as same as O2–2 (8)% Ag/SBA-15. With the increase of Ag loading, the SPR peak position for Ag catalysts pretreated with O2 is hardly changed, which should also be related with the Ag species effect. However an obvious blueshift is observed with the silver loading (>4wt%) for Ar pretreatment. The particle size begins a heavy aggregation to form larger particle size, and when the silver loading is increased to 8wt%, the particle size has been larger than that pretreated with oxygen. In addition, similar peak at 220nm is exhibited for Ar–6% Ag/SBA-15 and Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15, whereas Ar–4% Ag/SBA-15 does not. H2-TPR is a very useful technology to investigate the redox properties and phase composition of the catalysts. The results of H2-TPR performed on various 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts and 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . As can be seen, no obvious reduction peaks are found on Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 and H2–2% Ag/SBA-15, which is consistent with the UV–vis results (Fig. 3(A)). Two weak peaks (285, 461°C) are observed over O2–2% Ag/SBA-15. The peak at 285°C in our study is assigned to Ag2O clusters that existed outside of SBA-15 pores [6,13,17]. The peak at 461°C can be assigned to small sized Ag2O clusters that existed inside SBA-15 channels [6,13,17]. Further increasing Ag loading to 8wt%, the similar two peaks are also observed over both O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 and Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15 (Fig. 5(B)). It is found that the amount of Ag2O is obviously increased, and moreover more Ag2O is formed inside the channels. In conclusion, the pretreatment gas and Ag loading show a great influence on Ag particle size and Ag species state. A possible structure model of Ag crystallites is proposed and shown in Fig. 6 . When the silver loading is lower, the small metallic Ag0 nanoparticles is obtained after Ar pretreatment, and with the increase of Ag loading to 6wt%, some Ag nanoparticles aggregates to form a large one and a few Ag+ species appears (Fig. 4(D)). Further increasing Ag loading to 8wt%, the particle size has been larger than that pretreated with oxygen, and the amount of Ag2O is increased (Figs. 3 and 4(B)). It is also found that after Ar pretreatment the Ag+ or Ag2O will be formed only on the silver catalyst with higher loading (≥6wt%), and moreover most Ag2O is formed inside the channel of SBA-15. 3.2 Activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts Fig. 7 displays the temperature dependence of the CO conversions for various catalysts. It is clearly found that the activity of Ag/SBA-15 is highly sensitive to the pretreatment atmosphere. Of all 2wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts investigated, Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 shows the highest activity for CO oxidation (Fig. 7(A)). The temperature at which the conversion is 98% (T 98) for Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15 is 130°C, ca. 90°C below that for H2–2% Ag/SBA-15. Different situation occurs for the 8wt% Ag/SBA-15 catalysts. The highest activity for CO oxidation is observed on O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 (Fig. 7(B)). It is found that T 98 for Ag catalyst with low loading (2wt%) decreases in the series order Ar–2% Ag/SBA-15<O2–2% Ag/SBA-15<H2–2% Ag/SBA-15, and that T 98 for Ag catalyst with high loading (8wt%) decreases in the series order O2–8% Ag/SBA-15<Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15<H2–8% Ag/SBA-15. Our previous results have showed that the formation of subsurface oxygen during the high-temperature treatment plays a key role in the catalytic activity of silver catalysts for CO oxidation [18]. Here, no subsurface oxygen can be observed for the all catalysts pretreated with H2 at 500°C. As we all know that H2 treatment easily resulted in the aggregation of silver particles and the formation of Ag (111) surface [19]. Albers et al. also found that Ag (111) surface, the most stable crystallographic plane in silver particles, did not adsorb oxygen at all [19]. No CO adsorption took place on bare silver metal [20,21], which should be the reason that the lowest activity for CO oxidation is found on the H2-treated silver catalyst. It is also found that for 2wt% Ag/SBA-15, the best activity is obtained after Ar pretreatment; however for 8wt% Ag/SBA-15, oxygen pretreatment is benefit for the higher activity. In order to better interpret the relationship of the influence of O2 and Ar atmosphere on the catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 with different silver loading, turn over frequency (TOF) for CO oxidation at 25°C for Ag/SBA-15 with different silver loading is shown in Fig. 8 . TOF is calculated by moles of CO converted per mole Ag in the catalyst per hour. The catalysts are pretreated with oxygen and Ar, respectively. Interestingly, the activity decreases with the increase of silver loading when Ar pretreatment is conducted, however the activity increases with the increase of silver loading after oxygen pretreatment. It is well known that the changes in the silver morphology (particle size, states etc.) strongly influence oxygen adsorption, consequently affecting catalytic activity. High temperature oxygen treatment induces faceting of silver surface to high index planes with lower average coordination numbers, and thus more silver atoms are exposed on the surface. These high index planes are composed of more steps and kinks, which facilitate the formation of subsurface oxygen species and the increase of the CO oxidation activity [18,22]. Reports of strongly adsorbed subsurface oxygen species associated with metal silver species are prevalent in the literatures, and the large silver particles favor the formation of subsurface oxygen [23,24]. More subsurface oxygen species has been observed on the O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 9 . It has been shown that the particle size increases with the increase of silver loading. That is to say that the subsurface oxygen species tends to form on the silver catalysts with higher silver loading after oxygen pretreatment, and the ability of supplying subsurface oxygen species of silver catalysts enhances obviously. Therefore, it is believed that the activity of Ag catalyst with higher silver loading after O2 pretreatment is related with the structure (oxygen species) of silver particles. The formation of subsurface oxygen species after Ar pretreatment has also been observed, and it is believed that its formation is only related with the oxygen species decomposed from catalyst itself. Aneggi et al. have proposed the assumption by comparing the weight loss values (experimental vs theoretical) of the catalyst that all AgNO3 decomposes to metallic Ag according to the following two step process [25]. (1) 2AgNO3 →Ag2O+2NO2 +0.5O2 (2) Ag2O→2Ag+0.5O2 The amount of subsurface oxygen species and the formed Ag2O will be associated with the silver loading. This can well explain why that more Ag2O and subsurface oxygen species forms on the silver catalysts with higher loading after Ar pretreatment compared with the silver catalyst with low silver loading (Fig. 9). No contribution of gas oxygen species for the formation of subsurface oxygen species after Ar pretreatment results in the less amount of subsurface oxygen compared with the O2-preteratment. Thus the heavy aggregation of the silver particles and the small amount of subsurface oxygen species should be the reason for the low catalytic activity of Ar–8% Ag/SBA-15. For the silver catalyst with low Ag loading (≤6wt%), Ar pretreatment is favorable for the formation of metal Ag particles with small size. When the catalyst is treated with oxygen, the amount of the subsurface oxygen species is few and some Ag+ and Ag2O can be found on the catalyst (Figs. 4 and 9). It has been known that metallic Ag0 particles are active species and Ag particles with small size are favorable for the low temperature CO oxidation [7]. Moreover it has been found that the activity of Ar–6% Ag/SBA-15 has been comparable to O2–6% Ag/SBA-15 due to the presence of the mixture of Ag and Ag2O. Therefore, small metal Ag species is the key factor for the higher activity for the silver catalyst with low Ag loading (≤6wt%). Differently, for the silver catalyst with high silver loading, the large number of subsurface oxygen species plays an important role for the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In this paper, effects of pretreatment atmosphere and the silver loading on the structure and catalytic activity for CO oxidation of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts have been investigated. It is found that pretreatment atmosphere does not change physical structure of catalysts, but does change the structure (particle size, state and oxygen species) of Ag particles. Ar atmosphere strongly affects the states of Ag species for silver catalysts with different loadings, which is changed from metal Ag (≤4wt%) to a mixture of Ag and Ag2O (≥6wt%). Moreover Ar pretreatment is favorable for the formation of small Ag particles for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with lower Ag loading (≤6wt%). Compared with Ar pretreatment, O2 pretreatment is conductive to the formation of subsurface oxygen species on the larger silver particles for the Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with higher Ag loading, which results in the increase of TOF. The catalytic activity for CO oxidation decreases with the increase of silver loading when the silver catalyst is pretreated with Ar, and the reverse trend is obtained after oxygen pretreatment. The O2–8% Ag/SBA-15 exhibits the absolutely high TOF activity. It is proposed that the small metal Ag particle is the key factor for enhancing the catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with lower Ag loading, and the large number of subsurface oxygen species plays the essential effect for the high catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalyst when the silver loading is higher than 6wt%. Acknowledgements This work was supported financially by the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-09-0256), the National High Technology Research and Development Program of China (863 Program) (No. 2009AA062604), the National Nature Science Foundation of China (No. 20807010) and the Program for Liaoning representative office of China Environmental Protection Foundation (CEPF2010-123-1-10). coredata.dc:description: The structural properties of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts with various Ag loading after pretreatment under different atmosphere, i.e., O2, Ar and H2, in relation to their activities on CO oxidation were investigated. N2 adsorption–desorption results showed that the pretreatment atmosphere had a negligible effect on the physical structure of all catalysts. Interestingly, it was found that different pretreatment atmosphere (Ar, O2) and Ag loading exhibited a large difference on the structure of silver catalyst and their catalytic activity. For Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low silver loading (≤6wt%), Ar pretreatment resulted in the highest activity for CO oxidation. However, the highest catalytic performance was observed after oxygen pretreatment over the silver catalyst with high loading (>6wt%). UV–vis and H2-TPR results showed Ar pretreatment and Ag loading strongly affected the states of Ag species for the silver catalysts, which were changed from metal Ag (≤4wt%) to a mixture of Ag and Ag2O (≥6wt%). Moreover Ar pretreatment was favorable for the formation of small Ag particles for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low Ag loading. When the silver loading is increased, the heavy aggregation of silver particles occurred after Ar pretreatment, resulting in the decrease of TOF for CO oxidation. O2 pretreatment was conductive to the formation of subsurface oxygen species on the larger silver particles for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with high Ag loading, which resulted in the increase of TOF for CO oxidation. It was evident that small metal Ag particles was key factor of the higher catalytic activity for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with low Ag loading, while a large number of subsurface oxygen species played an important effect on the higher catalytic activity for Ag/SBA-15 catalyst with high Ag loading.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of pretreatment atmosphere and silver loading on the structure and catalytic activity of Ag/SBA-15 catalysts
